content.original:
The Roman dynasty was spread over many decades, and gave rise to some of the longest living systems of law, architecture, etc. Read on for a list of all the rulers of this great empire…
The history of the ancient empire of Rome has always managed to fascinate us. The Roman empire derives its origin from the Roman Republic after its ascent to the dominant power in Europe. Thus, Augustus, who is universally considered the first Roman emperor, was careful to always maintain the facade of republican rule, and did not take up any specific title to mark his rule, which began in 27 B.C. Given below is a list starting with Augustus until Justin II.
List of Roman Emperors
- Gaius Julius Caesar Augustus
- Tiberius Julius Caesar Augustus
- Gaius Julius Caesar Augustus Germanicus
- Tiberius Claudius Caesar Augustus Germanicus
- Nero Claudius Caesar Augustus Germanicus
- Servius Sulpicius Galba
- Marcus Salvius Otho
- Aulus Vitellius Germanicus
- Titus Flavius Vespasianus
- Titus Flavius Vespasianus
- Titus Flavius Domitianus
- Marcus Cocceius Nerva
- Marcus Ulpius Nerva Traianus
- Publius Aelius Hadrianus
- Titus Aurelius Fulvus Boionius Arrius Antoninus (Antoninus Pius)
- Lucius Aurelius Verus
- Marcus Aurelius Antoninus Augustus
- Lucius Aurelius Commodus Antoninus
- Publius Helvius Pertinax
- Marcus Didius Severus Julianus
- Lucius Septimius Severus
- Caracalla
- Publius Septimius Geta
- Marcus Opellius Macrinus
- Marcus Opellius Antoninus Diadumenianus
- Elagabalus
- Marcus Aurelius Severus Alexander
- Gaius Iulius Verus Maximinus (Maximinus I)
- Marcus Antonius Gordianus Sempronianus Romanus Africanus (Gordian I)
- Marcus Antonius Gordianus Sempronianus Romanus Africanus (Gordian II)
- Marcus Clodius Pupienus Maximus
- Decimus Caelius Calvinus Balbinus
- Marcus Antonius Gordianus Pius (Gordian III)
- Marcus Julius Philippus (Philip the Arab)
- Gaius Messius Quintus Decius
- Gaius Valens Hostilianus Messius Quintus
- Gaius Vibius Trebonianus Gallus
- Marcus Aemilius Aemilianus
- Publius Licinius Valerianus
- Publius Licinius Egnatius Gallienus
- Marcus Aurelius Claudius
- Marcus Aurelius Claudius Quintillus
- Lucius Domitius Aurelianus
- Marcus Claudius Tacitus
- Marcus Annius Florianus
- Marcus Aurelius Probus
- Marcus Aurelius Carus
- Marcus Aurelius Numerius Numerianus
- Marcus Aurelius Carinus
- Gaius Aurelius Valerius Diocletianus
- Marcus Aurelius Valerius Maximianus Herculius
- Flavius Valerius Constantius (Constantius Chlorus)
- Galerius Maximianus
- Flavius Valerius Severus
- Caesar Flavius Valerius Aurelius Constantinus Augustus (Constantine I or Emperor Constantine)
- Marcus Aurelius Valerius Maxentius
- Gaius Valerius Galerius Maximinus (Maximinus II)
- Valerius Licinianus Licinius
- Flavius Claudius Constantinus (Constantine II)
- Flavius Iulius Constantius (Constantius II)
- Flavius Julius Constans
- Flavius Claudius Iulianus (Julian the Apostate)
- Flavius Iovianus (Jovian)
- Flavius Valentinianus
- Flavius Julius Valens
- Flavius Gratianus
- Flavius Valentinianus (Valentinian II)
- Theodosius I
- Flavius Arcadius
- Flavius Honorius
- Flavius Theodosius (Theodosius II)
- Flavius Constantius (Constantius III)
- Joannes
- Flavius Placidius Valentinianus (Valentinian III)
- Flavius Marcianus
- Flavius Petronius Maximus
- Eparchius Avitus
- Flavius Iulius Valerius Maiorianus
- Flavius Libius Severus Serpentius
- Procopius Anthemius
- Anicius Olybrius
- Glycerius
- Julius Nepos
- Romulus Augustus
- Flavius Valerius Leo (Leo I the Thracian)
- Flavius Leo Junior (Leo II)
- Flavius Zeno
- Flavius Basiliscus
- Flavius Anastasius
- Flavius Iustinus (Justin I)
- Flavius Petrus Sabbatius Iustinianus (Justinian I)
- Flavius Iustinus (Junior) Augustus (Justin II)
Even though Romulus Augustus is considered to have been the last Roman emperor, he was actually an usurper, and is not included in the list. The decline of the Roman empire occurred due to increasingly strong enemies and treachery within the empire. However, no one can deny them the various achievements that marked the era, like their art, literature and architecture.

Even though Romulus Augustus is considered to have been the last Roman emperor, he was actually an usurper, and is not included in the list. The decline of the Roman empire occurred due to increasingly strong enemies and treachery within the empire. However, no one can deny them the various achievements that marked the era, like their art, literature and architecture.

One of the most pivotal events in Roman history was the assassination of Julius Caesar, which dramatically altered the course of the Republic and paved the way for imperial rule. On the Ides of March (March 15), 44 BC, Caesar was assassinated in the Theatre of Pompey, where the Senate was meeting. The conspiracy was led by a group of senators including Marcus Junius Brutus, Gaius Cassius Longinus, and several others who feared Caesar’s growing power threatened the Republic’s traditional governance. During the Senate session, Caesar was stabbed 23 times by the conspirators. According to historical accounts, Caesar initially resisted but ultimately succumbed, reportedly uttering the famous phrase "Et tu, Brute?" upon seeing Brutus among the attackers, symbolizing the betrayal by a trusted ally.

The assassination was motivated by political concerns over Caesar’s recent appointment as dictator for life and his perceived monarchical ambitions, which alarmed many senators who wished to preserve the Republic. The immediate aftermath plunged Rome into chaos. Mark Antony, Caesar’s loyal friend and co-consul, delivered a powerful funeral oration that swayed public opinion against the conspirators, inciting riots and unrest. This speech, immortalized by Shakespeare, marked the beginning of a series of civil wars that ultimately ended the Republic and led to the rise of Augustus as the first emperor. The assassination thus stands as a critical turning point, symbolizing the violent transition from republican governance to imperial autocracy.

The influence of Roman emperors extends far beyond their reigns, profoundly shaping modern Europe. The establishment and codification of Roman law under imperial rule became the foundation for many European legal systems, providing a framework for justice and governance that persists today. Their governance models, including centralized administration and bureaucratic structures, inspired medieval and modern statecraft, notably influencing the Holy Roman Empire and various European monarchies. The adoption of Christianity as a state religion under Emperor Constantine transformed the religious landscape of Europe, leading to the dominant role of the Catholic Church in medieval and modern European society. Roman architectural and engineering innovations set enduring standards for European urban development, infrastructure, and monumental building styles. Furthermore, the Byzantine Empire, as the Eastern Roman Empire, preserved and transmitted Roman culture and knowledge, sustaining classical learning that fueled the Renaissance and modern European intellectual traditions. Collectively, these legacies laid the groundwork for the political, legal, cultural, and religious development of modern Europe.

### Genealogy and Family Tree of Roman Emperors  
Understanding the familial relationships among Roman emperors is essential to grasp the dynastic nature of imperial succession and the political alliances that shaped the empire’s history. The Roman emperors often belonged to prominent dynasties, connected by blood, marriage, or adoption, which helped legitimize their rule and maintain continuity.

**Julio-Claudian Dynasty (27 BC – AD 68):**  
This first imperial dynasty began with Augustus (born Gaius Octavius), the adopted son and heir of Julius Caesar. Augustus was succeeded by his stepson and son-in-law Tiberius, followed by Caligula (Gaius Julius Caesar Augustus Germanicus), the great-grandson of Augustus. Claudius, Caligula’s uncle, then took the throne, succeeded by Nero, Claudius’s adopted son and great-great-grandson of Augustus through his mother. This dynasty was marked by complex family ties involving adoption and marriage to consolidate power.

**Flavian Dynasty (AD 69 – 96):**  
Following the Julio-Claudians, the Flavian dynasty was founded by Vespasian, who rose from a military background. His sons Titus and Domitian succeeded him. The Flavians were not related by blood to the Julio-Claudians but established their own imperial line.

**Nerva–Antonine Dynasty (AD 96 – 192):**  
This dynasty began with Nerva, who adopted Trajan as his heir. Trajan was succeeded by Hadrian, who was also adopted. Antoninus Pius followed, adopting Marcus Aurelius and Lucius Verus as co-heirs. Marcus Aurelius was succeeded by his biological son Commodus, marking the end of this dynasty. Adoption was a key mechanism for succession, emphasizing merit and stability.

**Severan Dynasty (AD 193 – 235):**  
Founded by Septimius Severus, this dynasty included his sons Caracalla and Geta, and later emperors related by marriage or adoption. The Severans emphasized military strength and centralized authority.

**Later Dynasties and Tetrarchy:**  
The empire’s later period saw the rise of emperors like Diocletian and Constantine, who established the Tetrarchy and later reunited the empire. Constantine’s family, the Constantinian dynasty, continued through his sons and relatives, often linked by blood and adoption.

These dynastic connections were often complex, involving adoptions, marriages, and political alliances rather than straightforward hereditary succession. Family trees of Roman emperors can be explored in detail through specialized genealogical charts available in historical texts and online resources.

For those interested in exploring these lineages further, ancestry platforms and genealogical research tools such as Ancestry.com, MyHeritage, and specialized Roman history databases provide detailed family trees and historical records. These resources allow users to trace the intricate relationships among emperors, their families, and their political networks, offering a deeper understanding of the imperial succession and its impact on Roman history.

### Documentaries on Roman Emperors  
In addition to historical texts, numerous documentaries have been produced to explore the lives and legacies of Roman emperors, offering visual and analytical insights into their reigns and the empire’s evolution. Notable documentaries include *"Rome: Rise and Fall of an Empire"*, which provides a detailed chronological overview of key emperors and pivotal events, and *"The Roman Empire: Reign of Blood"*, which dramatizes the political intrigue and power struggles of the imperial court. These documentaries are praised for their combination of expert interviews, archaeological evidence, and reenactments, making the complex history accessible to a broad audience. For those interested in the cultural and architectural achievements of the empire, *"Engineering an Empire: Rome"* highlights the technological innovations under various emperors. Collectively, these documentaries complement the historical record by bringing to life the personalities and challenges that shaped the Roman Empire’s enduring legacy.

### Audiobooks on Augustus  
For those interested in exploring the life and reign of Augustus through audio format, several notable audiobooks provide comprehensive and engaging narratives. *"Augustus: The Life of Rome's First Emperor"* by Anthony Everitt, narrated by John Curless, offers a detailed biography that traces Augustus’s rise from the chaos of the late Republic to his establishment of the Roman Empire. This audiobook is praised for its accessible storytelling and rich historical context, making it ideal for listeners seeking an in-depth understanding of Augustus’s political acumen and legacy. Another recommended title is *"The Roman Empire: From Augustus to the Fall of Rome"* by Gregory S. Aldrete, which provides a broader overview of the empire’s history beginning with Augustus’s reign. This audiobook combines scholarly insight with engaging narration, appealing to those interested in the wider imperial narrative alongside Augustus’s pivotal role.

These audiobooks are widely available for download or streaming on platforms such as Audible, Audiobooks.com, and OverDrive, often offered in multiple formats including MP3 and streaming options compatible with various devices. Availability may vary by region, but these platforms provide convenient access for both casual listeners and serious students of Roman history. Incorporating audiobooks into your study or leisure time offers a dynamic way to engage with the enduring story of Augustus and the Roman Empire.

### Recommended Books on Julius Caesar  
For readers seeking authoritative literary resources on Julius Caesar, several well-regarded biographies and historical analyses provide deep insight into his life, military campaigns, and political impact. *"Julius Caesar"* by Philip Freeman offers a concise yet comprehensive biography that balances Caesar’s military genius with his political ambitions. Adrian Goldsworthy’s *"Caesar: Life of a Colossus"* is a detailed and scholarly work praised for its thorough research and engaging narrative, providing a nuanced portrait of Caesar’s rise and fall. Another notable title is *"Rubicon: The Last Years of the Roman Republic"* by Tom Holland, which situates Caesar within the broader context of the Republic’s collapse and the dawn of imperial rule. These books serve as essential reading for anyone interested in understanding the complexities of Julius Caesar’s legacy and his pivotal role in Roman history.

### Recommended Books on Roman Emperors  
To complement the focused works on Julius Caesar and the audiobooks on Augustus, several comprehensive books cover the broader scope of Roman emperors, offering detailed accounts of their reigns, political challenges, and contributions to the empire’s legacy. *"The Twelve Caesars"* by Suetonius, translated by Robert Graves, remains a classic, providing vivid biographies of the first twelve emperors, blending historical facts with intriguing anecdotes. For a more modern and scholarly perspective, *"The Roman Emperors: A Biographical Guide to the Rulers of Imperial Rome, 31 BC–AD 476"* by Michael Grant offers concise yet informative profiles of each emperor, ideal for readers seeking a thorough overview. Another highly recommended title is *"Imperial Rome: 31 BC to AD 284: The Critical Century"* by Pat Southern, which explores the political and social dynamics of the empire’s formative centuries under imperial rule. These books are widely available through major booksellers such as Amazon, Barnes & Noble, and independent bookstores, often offered in both print and digital formats. Purchasing these works provides readers with authoritative and accessible resources to deepen their understanding of the complex history and enduring influence of Roman emperors.

### Roman Emperors Timeline Posters  
For students, educators, and history enthusiasts seeking a visual and educational tool, Roman emperors timeline posters offer an engaging way to explore the succession and historical context of the empire’s rulers. Typically, these posters feature a chronological layout of emperors, often accompanied by family trees, portraits, and key dates marking significant events during each reign. The visual design usually combines clear typography with artistic depictions of emperors and iconic Roman symbols, making them both informative and decorative.

These posters are commonly used in classrooms to aid teaching about Roman history, in libraries and study rooms for quick reference, or as decorative pieces for those passionate about ancient history. When selecting a quality timeline poster, it is advisable to look for prints that use durable materials and high-resolution images to ensure longevity and clarity. Popular brands such as National Geographic, Historical Maps, and Pomegranate offer well-designed posters, often available in laminated formats for added durability. Some retailers also provide customizable options, allowing buyers to add personal notes or select specific emperors to highlight.

Roman emperors timeline posters can be purchased through trusted online retailers like Amazon, where a wide range of price points typically ranges from $15 to $50 depending on size and quality. Museum gift shops, including those at the British Museum and the Roman-Germanic Museum in Cologne, also stock exclusive and high-quality posters. Specialty history stores and educational supply websites offer curated selections, often bundled with complementary materials such as maps of the Roman Republic and Empire or detailed timelines of key events. For the best value, buyers should consider the poster’s print quality, material (such as laminated or matte finish), and the inclusion of supplementary educational content. Choosing laminated posters can enhance durability, while matte finishes reduce glare for easier reading. High-resolution prints ensure clarity of portraits and text, making the posters ideal for study and display. Customization options available from some vendors allow educators and enthusiasts to tailor the content to specific learning goals or personal interests.

These posters serve as valuable tools to complement textual and documentary resources, helping to visualize the continuity and complexity of Roman imperial leadership. Whether used for study, decoration, or quick historical reference, Roman emperors timeline posters provide an accessible and engaging way to connect with the rich history of the Roman Empire.

### Related Topics: Caesars Palace Gift Cards  
For those interested in modern-day Caesars Palace, gift cards offer a convenient way to enjoy the luxury and entertainment of this iconic resort. Caesars Palace gift cards can be ordered both online and in-person. To purchase online, visit the official Caesars Entertainment website, where you can select the card amount, typically ranging from $25 to $500. A convenience fee of around $5 may apply depending on the card value and delivery method. In-person purchases are available at Caesars Palace retail locations and casino cages, where staff can assist with immediate issuance.

These gift cards can be used across Caesars Entertainment properties, including hotels, restaurants, casinos, and shops, providing flexibility for dining, gaming, and accommodations. Terms and conditions generally include a validity period of up to five years, no expiration on the funds, and the ability to reload the card. Benefits of using a Caesars Palace gift card include easy budgeting for trips, gifting options for friends and family, and seamless integration with Caesars Rewards for earning loyalty points. Clear instructions for ordering emphasize verifying the recipient’s details and choosing between physical or digital delivery to suit convenience.
